Posts.Content: On 9/7/2007 Grandma Bev wrote: Hello Feeling Alone, My heart goes out to you. I'm an 11 year survivor and doing well. I was in your situation and I chose the lumpectomy instead of masesctomy. My cancer was located in the chest wall. They had to go in with a lead wire to get to it. My doctor said other patients that had their cancer located in the same area, got cancer again, even after the masectomy. I underwent 35 radiation treatments. Where is the lump located? There's also a P.E.T. scan they can run to see if theres any cancer cells movement in the nodes and anywhere else. Dont know if you've had one or not. The P.E.T. scan showed that my surgeon had gotten every floating microscopic cell when he decided how much tissue to take out along with the tumor. I'm tired and fat now, but I'm alive and try to count my blessing every day.   I hope you make the choices that are right for you..... I hope to hear back.   Beverly in Ohio       thank you beverly for responding to my letter, i have made my decision to go with the mastectomy, ifeel this will be my best and safest choice, i have not heard of this scan, its been very hard to decide what to do and i feel good with this decision and i'm praying so hard its the right one and i just felt that goingwith treatment only left me with bad odds,. i will talk to my doctor about this scan and if this is something my insurance will cover maybe i'll give it a shot before anything is done. where can i find info on this?

Posts.Content: On 9/6/2007 Oncrx wrote: You mentioned you were stage 1 yet had LN involvement.  This would be stage II at a minimum.  From your path report it would be helpful to know ER/PR status, HER status, Ki 67 and tumor grade.  One option to ask your doc about is Oncotype Dx which is a gene profile which will help determine your chance of recurrance.  If low , then lumpectomy and adjuvant therapy is probably OK.  If high, then you may want to consider a mastectomy.  Keep in mind a mastectomy is an unlikely option down the road if this recurs as metastatic disease. thank you thank you this has been very helpful and i will follow up on this today, your advise really helped me

Posts.Content: On 9/6/2007 Corinjeff wrote: Hi I saw your message, and just had to reply to you. I was feeling exactly the same way in Oct 06 when told I had breast cancer... I had just returned from my father's funeral, he died from undiagnosed cancer metastactic..... from diag to death in 4 days... I was feeling the same way, I had microcalcifications in two places, no lump... two biopsies, I felt my body had let me down, I eat right, excercise etc etc, so it was a mastectomy, and with 4 nodes positive and her2 I was stage 2b with absoloutely no symptoms other than detection from a mamagram. I came through it well, hardly any pain, recovered fine went to work in 4 days, then started chemo in Feb 07 had mastectomy in Dec06.. Did pretty well om chemo, finished since May 07, have been looking at lots of alternative supplements, and now taking PAW PAW I believe that is the way to go and other whole food supplements. Listen to your Dr, and also your gut feeling, then ask lots of questions, question everything.... I did... good luck and let us know how you are doing. Corinne dear corinne,  thank you, i meet with my doctor and we decide the best was a mastectomy and i now how peace of mind and believe this is best so now i'll be meeting with a plastic surgeon to do reconstructive surgery at the same time, so ill only have to face chemo and hormone treatment i just don't think i would have peace of mind under only treatment i feel good about my decision and can now move forward. i believe in herbal supplements and will follow threw with that after all the big stuff gets out of way. i did herbs for years and then quit, i will go back to it

Posts.Content: On 9/7/2007 Snowmom60 wrote: I am so glad you decided to have the masectomy!!!!!!!!  Here's a situation:  Back in 1991 my mother in law was DX with breast CA, she had 19 out of 21 lymph nodes and it was grade IV she decided to have a lumpectomy since her surgeon told her it wouldn't make any difference.  My neighbor about the same age (50's) was DX about a month later and had about 23 lymph nodes positive.  She went to the medical college and decided to have a double masectomy.  My mother in law died five years later, my neighbor died 9 years later they were both stage IV.  Your very, very early stage, do what it takes, boobs are only boobs.  My neighbor had her breasts done and a tummy tuck at the same time and looked better than before the cancer.  Both of my husbands grandmothers also had breast cancer and one is alive and the other is 87 right now, they were both stage I so be positive.  I worry about my daughter and we're thinking about genetic testing for her, although I think it may be because all three of them were on hormone replace therapy for menopause but still we want to know if we can prevent it if she has the genes. Good luck! Terry thank you terry, i just have this gut feeling that this is the right choice and like you say boobs are boobs and they will be doing the tummy tuck, i teased the girls at work i might be 53 but when i get done i'll be a hot 53 haha i had several little signs that might be weird to some people but i took it as my angels sending me a message,  i belong to a club where i by these dolls for my granddaughter, my mother passed away 10 years ago akidney transplant patient, i came home from doc and behind my door was a box, i notified the doll company several weeks ago to stop sending dolls for a while, well when i seen this box i said no they shouldn't sent this but opened anyway, well the dolls name is rosie and she was the first doll in cancer series she is the breast cancer doll and my mom's name was rosie!!!!!!!!  several weeks prior in mail came some type of advertistment with my name on it i opened and it was two bookmarkers with angels on and my name printed above the angels, i thought nothing of it untill i received that doll and thought it was a message from mom that all will be ok, and that how i came to the conclusion to go with the mastectomy, may sound weird, but my heart tells me its mom, i didn't think much of the book markers until i made my decision, then i remebered them and looked thru the pile of mail  in hopes i still had them and i did.  so my angels are watching me and i'm going to beat this and live to see my grandchildren for a very long time

Posts.Content: On 9/6/2007 Njtwinmom wrote: Sorry to hear of your illness. I have not gone through it, but my Grandmother did, and  I did work for OB/GYN physicians for 20 years, so I saw alot more than the average person. My gut feeling is that if they want you to "consider" the surgery---GO FOR IT!! Why take the chance?  I always said that is what I would do in that case.  Anything that can be done to assure that there is less of a chance for the cancer to return, I would take. That is only my opinion, and I hope that you are successful, in whatever course of action you take. Beth thank you beth it feels good to know someone else's opinion and with your background helps even more.

Posts.Content: On 9/18/2007 tinkerbellisme wrote: I don't know what part of the country you're in, but perhaps there is a specialty center in a surrounding city.  When my mom was diagnosed, the local surgeon she was reffered to by her family doctor (who actually specialized in heart surgery, not breast) postponed her scheduled surgery for 3 additional weeks (it had already been almost 2 months sincer her actual diagnosis) because he had a golf vacation coming up.  I know that many doctors will tell you that a delay doesn't matter, but when it's your life or that of someone you care about, every single day makes a difference!!  I'm very glad he did postpone her surgery though.  Since she told us, my entire family had been begging her to see a specialist.  She finally relented after that cancellation.  From that day, it took less than a week to have her surgery by an amazing breast cancer specialist.  He was so caring, compassionate, and professional.  I  didn't know doctors like that still existed....especially surgeons.  If you are in MD, DC, PA, VA or anywhere near, let me know and I would be happy to give you his info.thank you not in those areas,  got date, its wednesday  finally on the road to recovery!!!!!
